en.av_c1: Let's think about the domino effect in terms of recursion. When you stand up a bunch of dominos properly, pushing the first one causes all of the others to fall over one by one until the last domino is reached.
en.av_c2: To model the domino effect recursively, think of it as a function to tip n dominos over. Use the functional notation Domino(n) to represent the solution on $n$ dominos. Thus, Domino(1) is the solution to tip a single domino over, Domino(2) is the solution to tip two, Domino(3) is the solution to tip three, etc.
en.av_c3: If there is only one domino, we just tip it over manually. This is the base case, solved by calling function TipOver(1).
en.av_c4: If there are two dominos, after the first domino is tipped over the second domino will be tipped over subsequently. So, Domino(2) is solved by executing Domino(1), followed by tipping the second domino over.
en.av_c5: Similarly, if there are three dominos, after the first and second dominos are tipped over, the third domino will be tipped over subsequently. So, Domino(3) is solved by executing Domino(2) (to tip over the first two dominos) followed by tipping the third domino over.
en.av_c6: More generally, Domino(n) is solved by executing Domino(n-1), followed by tipping the $n$th domino over.
en.av_c8: Of course, the call to Domino(n-1) recursively reduces the problem in the recursion winding phase
en.av_c9: When the base case is reached, domino 1 is tipped.
en.av_c10: In the recursion unwindng phase, dominoes 2,3,..., $n$ are tipped one after the other.
